How the hell did you do that?
I couldn't wait till tomorrow.
If you bring the caramels.
Promise?
You should have called. I have an "O- chem" lab due tomorrow and it's impossible.  It's not an excuse dummy. I want to go out with you. But look:
Sorry. I'm sorry. Give me another crack at it. Let me take you out.
You were busy? You know, I really was waiting for you to call me.
I'm sorry, I been real busy.
Where have you been?
We'll do that.
I want to meet them.
All the time. We all live in Southie. I live with three of them now.
Do you keep in touch with them?
Marky, Ricky, Danny, Terry, Mikey, Davey, Timmy, Tommy, Joey, Robby, Johnny, and Brian.
Well...
'Course I do, they're my brothers.
Do you know all their names?
It was great. There was always someone to play with, give you advice.
Your house must have been a zoo.
I swear to God.
Bullshit.
Yup, you're lookin' at lucky thirteen.
Not a chance.
I have twelve big brothers.
What, five?
You wouldn't believe me if I told you.
How many?
Well, Irish Catholic. What do you think?
Yeah.
Do I have a lot of brothers and sisters?
You have a lot of brothers and sisters?
You know, nothing special.
I bet you have a great family.
Pretty boring, I guess.
How was that?
Not far from here, South Boston.
You grew up around here?
Hey, I spent all my money on those caramels.
Free?
Then why don't we just get it out of the way.
No...I was hoping to get a kiss.
Oh, you will?
I was kinda' hopin' to get a "good night laid" but...I'll take a kiss.
Yes you were.
No I wasn't...
Yes you have. You were thinking you were gonna get a good night kiss.
No I haven't...
You know what I mean. I know you've at least thought about it.
I really don't 'date' that much.
Well, there's this part of the movie that's about how there's always this tension on a first date where both people are thinking about what's going to happen with the whole 'good night kiss' thing.
No.
Have you ever seen Annie Hall?
Okay...
Now, I'm gonna make all these caramels disappear.
Sure.
In that case, fine.  Want to see my magic trick?
Well, I'm gonna experiment on you for my anatomy class, then go.
So you just want to use me and go?
Stanford. I'm leaving in June after I graduate.
Is Harvard gettin' all that money?
I was happy to pay. I inherited the money.
I bet your parents were happy to pay.

I don't know, it was just kind of the boring suburban thing. Private school, Harvard, and now Med. School.  I actually figured out that at the end of it, my brain will be worth a quarter of a million dollars. I shouldn't have told you that...
You aren't, by any chance, Pre-law? Are you?
Sounds good, where are you now?
Yeah, I figured maybe sometime this week we could go to a cafe and have some caramels.
Oh Will! I was wondering when you'd call.
Okay, you got me. It's the ugly, obnoxious, toothless loser who got drunk and wouldn't leave you alone all night.
I'm sorry, I don't recall meeting anyone who fits that description.
It's Will, the really funny good looking guy you met at the bar?
Yeah?
The caramel thing is my pick-up line.
See, it's my life story. Five more minutes and I would have got to hear your best pick-up line.
I was trying to be smooth.  But at twelve-fifteen I was gonna come over there and talk to you.
What?
Five minutes.
Okay, sounds good.
When you think about it, it's just as arbitrary as drinking coffee.
What?
Great, or maybe we could go somewhere and just eat a bunch of caramels.
Here's my number.
I didn't mean you. Listen, maybe...
Well, look, I have to go. Gotta' get up early and waste some more money on my overpriced education.
I kind of got that impression.
Skylar. And by the way. That guy over there is a real dick and I just wanted you to know he didn't come with us.
I'm Will.
I've been sitting over there for forty- five minutes waiting for you to come talk to me. But I'm just tired now and I have to go home and I wasn't going to keep sitting there waiting for you.
What?
You suck.
Joe!

Twicet now I've fell for that line. Maybe he needs a thousan' men. So he get's five thousan' there, an' he'll pay fifteen cents a hour. An' you guys'll have to take it 'cause you'll be hungry.  'F he wants to hire men, let him write it out an' say what he's gonna pay. Ast to see his license. He ain't allowed by law to contrack men without a license.
Listen, Smart Guy. I'll run my business my own way. I got work. If you wanta take it, okay. If not, just sit here, that's all.
'F we're workin' for you, it's our business too. An' how do we know--  --you ain't one a the guys that sent these things out?
You trying to tell me how to run my own business?
All right, mister. I'll go. You just show your license to contrack, an' then you make out a order--where an' when an' how much you gonna pay--an' you sign it an' we'll go.
Well, I'm contracting the land.
You doin' the hirin'?
Be glad to get my han' on some cotton. That's the kin' a pickin' I understan'.
Twenty days work, oh boy!
Let 'er go, Gallagher!
Ready, Pa?
Sure! I was just aimin' to meet up with a couple girls I know.
Leave him alone, Ma--Al's just billy- goatin' around--
I never knowed they was anything like her!
Will ya look at her!
Reckon we better begin roustin' 'em out if we aim to get outa here by daylight. How about it, John? How you boys comin'?
She'll prob'ly ride like a bull calf-- but she'll ride!
Sure. Why not?
Okay. I think you're a darn fool, though.
Lissen. I don't care nothin' about you, but if you mess in this, your whole fambly li'ble to get in trouble, an' Tom get sent back to the penitentiary.
But ain't no reason--
*Some*body got to take the blame. They just *got* to hang it on somebody, you know.  An' I ain't doin' nothin' but set around.
How 'bout you?
Go on. Get in your tent. You don't know nothin'.
Look at that ol' coffeepot steam!

Woman can change better'n a man. Man lives in jerks--baby born, or somebody dies, that's a jerk--gets a farm, or loses one, an' that's a jerk. With a woman it's all one flow, like a stream, little eddies, little waterfalls, but the river it goes right on. Woman looks at it like that.
Watch me pass that Chevvy.

No. Ain't ever gonna be scared no more.  I was, though. For a while I thought we was beat--*good* an' beat. Looked like we didn't have nothin' in the worl' but enemies--wasn't *no*body frien'ly anymore. It made me feel bad an' scared too--like we was lost... an' nobody cared.
Whatsa matter, Ma? Gettin' scared?
Maybe. Maybe twenny days work, maybe *no* days work. We ain't got it till we get it.
I'll get Rosasharn.
Ready, Ma?

Well, you ain't a-goin'! Ain't *nobody* else a-goin'! We *got* here an' we gonna *stay* here, together! As long as we got the fambly unbroke I ain't scared, but it's a long bitter road we got ahead of us--  --an' I'm here to tell ya ef anybody else tries to bust us up anymore I'm a-goin' cat wild with this here piece a bar-arn!
But it ain't runnin' away, Ma. All I wanta do is go away with another fella an' look aroun' for work by ourself--
But ef you *do* whup me, I swear you better not ever go to sleep again, because the minute you go to sleep, or you're settin' down, or your back's turned, I'm gonna knock you belly-up with a bucket.
I'd come back--
I never had my house pushed over before. I never had my fambly stuck out on the road. I never had to lose... ever'thing I had in life.
That don't sound like you, Ma. You never was like that before.
We're goin' to California, ain't we? Awright then, let's *go* to California.
Ain't you gonna look back, Ma?--give the ol' place a last look?
Now I can't breathe.
That comes from not holdin' you tight *enough.*
You're *ticklin' me!*
Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!
Don't hold me so tight.
Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm *I* doin'?
She got to make it.
Looks like about a mile. Reckon she'll make it?
Well, looks like we done it this time awright!
Gallon or two?
Any gas?
Fan-belt's shot.
She's hotter'n a heifer.
Thing's been workin' on me, what they was yellin' about. Got me all curious.
Think I'll look aroun' an' see if I can't meet me a girl.
I don't know what these cops got to do with it but I don't like it.  An' these here are our own people, all of 'em. I don't like this.
Maybe the road's out.
We got to get outa here right away. Ever'body here? Where's Uncle John?
Tom? You can come on. They gone.
Well, we ain't out a it yet.
Lots must a died, too.
People done it. If they could, we could.
What a place! How'd you like to walk acrost her?
Oh.
Naw. They paroled me.
You bust outa jail, Tom?
Okay. Go on.
I didn't see nothin'.
Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?
Short fella. Pale face.
What'd he look like again?
We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.
I guess that's what he looked like.
You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?
Hey, wait a minute. You got change comin'.
So long.
Them was nickel apiece candy.
What's it to you?
Them wasn't two-for-a-cent candy.
Cut me off a hunk a that banana cream, and a cuppa java.
Banana cream, pineapple cream, chocolate cream--and apple.
Kinda pie y'got?
Okay. House 63. Wages 5 cents a box. No bruised fruit. Move along and go to work right away.
Why, I guess so.
Can all of you work?
Two.
Kids?
Two.
Women?
Four.
How many men?
Joad.
That's not your affair. Name.
Sure, but what is this?
Want to work?
Which way is House 25?
Look, I didn't set the price. I'm just working here. If you want it, take it. If you don't, turn right around and beat it.
But--but how we gonna eat?
Take it or leave it. There's 200 men coming from the South that'll be glad to get it.
Two an' a half! Say, mister, a man can't make his dinner on that.
Two and a half cents.
Okay, mister. Whatcha payin'?
House 25. Number's on the door.
Well, I don't know what you gonna do about it, because I don't hear no riot an' I don't see no riot, an' what's more I don't believe they *is* no riot.  Look for yourself.
We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.
Got a warrant?
Deputy sheriffs.
Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?
Open up! We hear you got a riot.
Goodnight.
Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.
Crate fell on me.
That cut you got?
Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.
Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.
Anything like work aroun' here?
*You* find out, I can't.
Why ain't they more like it?
Government.
Say, who runs this place?
We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.
You got dances too?
They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.
I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.
No cop can come in here without a warrant.
An' you say no cops?
That's the way it is.
Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?
We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.
We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?
Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.
How many of you?
Joad. Tom Joad.
I don't mean to be nosy, y'understand. I just got to have certain information. What's your name?
I hear it. I think they's some guys comin' this way, lots of 'em. We better get outa here.
Can't tell if you hear it or not. You hear it, Tom?
Got to learn, like I'm a-learnin'. Don't know it right yet myself, but I'm tryin' to fin' out. That's why I can't ever be a preacher again. Preacher got to *know*.  I don't. I got to *ask*.

We was outa food. Tonight we had meat. Not much, but we had it. Think Pa's gonna give up his meat on account a other fellas? An' Rosasharn needs milk. Think Ma's gonna starve that baby jus' cause a bunch a fellas is yellin' outside a gate?
I guess that's right. Have to take a beatin' before he'll know.
But jus' the minute they ain't strike- breakin' they won't get no five!
They won't. They're a-gettin' five an' they don't care about nothin' else.

Try an' tell 'em, Tom. They'll get two an' a half, jus' the minute we're gone. An' you know what that is? That's one ton a peaches picked an' carried for a dollar. That way you can't even buy food enough to keep you alive! Tell 'em to come out with us, Tom! Them peaches is *ripe*. Two days out an' they'll pay *all* of us five!
I'll tell 'em. But I don't know how. Never seen so many guys with guns. Wouldn't even let us talk today.

Well--tell the folks inside how it is, Tom. Tell 'em they're starvin' us and stabbin' theirself in the back. An' as sure as God made little apples it's goin' back to two an' a half jus' as soon as they clear us out.
I aim to.
I don't expeck we can las' much longer-- some a the folks ain't et for two days. You goin' back tonight?
I dunno. Payin' five now.

Lookie, Tom. We come to work here. They tell us it's gonna be fi' cents. But they was a whole lot of us, so the man says two an' a half cents. Well, a fella can't even eat on that, an' if he got kids...  So we says we won't take it. So they druv us off. Now they're payin' you five--but when they bust this strike ya think they'll pay five?
No, I done my time an' got out. Come on in.
Thought you was in jail.
Well, if it ain't Tom Joad. How ya, boy?
Casy! What you doin' here?
What's the matter?
Hide in the willows. If it's awright to come back I'll give you four high whistles.
You're right!
He seen you, Tom! You wanta be fingerprinted? You wanta get sent back for breakin' parole?
I ain't gonna run.
Gimme that gun. Now git outa here. Go down in them willows an' wait.
I don't know.
How about us? Is that the truth for us?

I'll say 'em--an' make it short.  This here ol' man jus' lived a life an' jus' died out of it. I don't know whether he was good or bad, an' it don't matter much. Heard a fella say a poem once, an' he says, "All that lives is holy." But I wouldn't pray for jus' a ol' man that's dead, because he's awright. If I was to pray I'd pray for the folks that's alive an' don't know which way to turn. Grampa here, he ain't got no more trouble like that. He's got his job all cut out for 'im--so cover 'im up and let 'im get to it.
We know. But ain't none of our folks ever been buried without a few words.
I ain't no more a preacher, you know.
If she does it'll be a miracle outa Scripture.
Think she'll hold?
It's hard to say. Stay here till mornin' an' then go on over to Uncle John's, I reckon. After that I don't know.
What you figger to do?
She's settlin'.
All right, you remember the *man* then.
I ain't no preacher anymore.
This is Muley Graves.  You remember the preacher, don't you?
I never heard nothin' about it.
This used to be mine. I give it to Grampa when I went away.  You reckon they could be dead?
No. They wasn't people to write.
They never wrote you nothing?
They're all gone--or dead.
That's our place.
Your granma was a great one, too. The third time she got religion she go it so powerful she knocked down a full-growed deacon with her fist.
Just around that next bend.
Is it fur?
Shore it is. It always is, this time a year.
Lissen. This wind's fixin't to *do* somepin'!

I'll be glad to see you pa. Last time I seen him was at a baptizin', an' he had one a the bigges' doses of the Holy Sperit I ever seen. He go to jumpin' over bushes, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon-time. Fin'ly he picks hisself out a bush big as a piana an' he let out a squawk an' took a run at that bush. Well, sir, he cleared her but he bust his leg snap in two. They was a travellin' dentist there and he set her, an' I give her a prayin' over, but they wasn't no more Holy Sperit in your pa after that.
Maybe Ma'll have pork for supper. I ain't had pork but four times in four years--every Christmas.
It don't matter. Ever since I lost the sperit it looks like I just as soon go one way as the other.  I'll go your way.
No, but I aim to before sundown. Gettin' kind of excited about it, too. Which way you going?
Ain't you seen your folks since then?
He had a knife in me. That's why they only gave me seven years. Got out in four--parole.
And you ain't ashamed?
I don't mind any more. I'd do what I done again. I killed a guy at a dance. We was drunk. He got a knife in me and I laid him out with a shovel. Knocked his head plumb to squash.
Excuse me for asking.
I been in the penitentiary for four years.
No, I never. What?
Didn't you hear? It was in the papers.
Been out travelin' around?
Ought to be. That's fact'ry liquor. Cost me a buck.
Course I'll say grace if somebody sets out the food--  --but my heart ain't in it.  Nice drinkin' liquor.
Have a little snort?

But you wasn't a preacher. A girl was just a girl to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls.  I ast myself--what *is* this call, the Holy Sperit? Maybe *that's* love. Why, I love everybody so much I'm fit to bust sometimes!  So maybe there ain't no sin an' there ain't no virtue. There's just what people do. Some things folks do is nice, and some ain't so nice. But that's as far as any man's got a right to say.
I never let one go by me when I could catch her.

At my meetin's I used to get the girls glory-shoutin' till they about passed out. Then, I'd go to comfort 'em--and always end up by lovin' 'em. I'd feel bad, an' pray, an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Next time, do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me.
Maybe you should a got yourself a wife.
I got nothin' to preach about no more--that's all. I ain't so sure o' things.
Pa always said you was never cut out to be a preacher.

*Used* to be. Not no more. I lost the call.  But boy, I sure *used* to have it! I'd get an irrigation ditch so squirmin' full of repented sinners I pretty near *drowned* half of 'em!  But not no more. I lost the sperit.
Why, you're the preacher!
Well, I do declare!  I baptized you, son.
Yeah. On my way home now.
Say, ain't you young Tom Joad--ol' Tom's boy?
I ought to done it then--an' not come on any trip like this.
But we can still do it, honey.
No, but--but you seen that advertisement in the Spicy Western Story magazine. Don't pay nothin'. Jus' send 'em the coupon an' you're a radio expert--nice clean work.
You ain't--you ain't sorry, are you, honey?
Women is always tar'd.
Seems like we wasn't never gonna do nothin' but move. I'm so tar'd.
Little trouble up ahead, but you'll get through. Just follow the line.
What's the matter? What's happened?
Pull up behind that car.  Okay for this one. Take 'em through.
Sure do.
Want to work, do you?
Fella named Spencer sent us--said they was work pickin' peaches.
Lissen, I heard that before--
We ain't campin'. We jus' stoppin' a minute--
Save your strength, lady.  Get goin', buddy. No campin' here.
They shore don't waste no time!  Take her out.
You ain't gonna blow nobody nowhere. First place, you'd get hung and you know it. For another, it wouldn't be two days before they'd have another guy here to take my place.
Have it your own way, son, but just as sure as you touch my house with that cat I'm gonna blow you plumb to kingdom come.
*Used* to be your land. B'longs to the comp'ny now.
But this is *my land*, son. Don't you understand?

For three dollars a day, that's what I'm doin' it for. I got two little kids. I got a wife and my wife's mother. Them people got to eat. Fust and on'y thing I got to think about is my own folks. What happens to other folks is their lookout.
Then what are you doin' this kind a thing for--against your own people?
I don't like nobody drawin' a bead on me.
Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.
I never asked you!
That's where I get off.
Yeah.
Me neither. I'm just tryin' to get along without shovin' anybody around, that's all.  See that road up ahead?
I didn't mean nothing.
Go ahead. Ask me anything you want.
You ain't got to get sore.
Listen. That big nose of yours been goin' over me like a sheep in a vegetable patch. But I ain't keepin' it a secret. I been in the penitentiary. Been there four years. Like to know anything else?
I stay in my own yard.
Naw--not much!
I don't stick my nose in nobody's business.
You know what I mean. You been givin' me a goin' over ever since I got in. Whyn't you go on and ask me where I been?
Get to what?
Why don't you get to it, buddy?
I seen your hands. You been swinging a pick or a sledge--that shines up your hands. I notice little things like that all the time.  Got a trade?
Yeah.
Been doin' a job?
Oh!
No, my old man got a place, forty acres. He's a sharecropper, but we been there a long time.
Lookin' for a job?
Just a few miles. I'd a walked her if my dogs wasn't pooped out.
Goin' far?
Can't you see that sticker?
How about a lift, mister?
It don't take no nerve to do somep'n when there ain't nothin' else you can do.
Well, maybe. But I'd hate to be doin' it. Takes more nerve than I got.
If we broke down maybe somebody'd give us a han'.
Sure, plenty, but not in no wreck like this.
You been acrost?
Crossin' the desert in a jalopy like this.
What you mean?
You people got a lotta nerve.
Five they're a-gettin' now, an' that's all they're int'rested in. I know exackly what Pa'd say. He'd jus' say it wasn't none a his business.
An' the nex' thing you know you'll be out, because they got it all figgered down to a T--until the harvest is in you're a *migrant* worker--afterwards, just a bum.
Sure. We made a buck since midday.
Fi' cents! They pain' you fi' cents?
Well, fi' cents a box ain't much, but a fella can eat.
This here's a strike.
Workin'. Pickin' peaches. But I seen a bunch a fellas yellin' when we come in, so I come out to see what's goin' on. What's it all about?
Didn' none of these have no breakfast?
No, ma'am. They ain't no work hereabouts. Pa's in tryin' to sell some stuff to get gas so's we can get along.
Didn' you have no breakfast?
Yes, ma'am.
You want to get ast to eat, hunh?
I could break up some bresh if you want me, ma'am.
Hush!
What's he fixin' to do, ma?
Put somepin' over him, so he won't git sun-struck.  Ever'body set now?  Awright, Al, letta go!
Ain't a-goin', thas all...
Easy, *easy!* You wanta bust his head wide open? Pull his arms, John.

And I ain't gonna listen either. I tol' you what I'm gonna do.  And I don't give a hoot in a hollow if they's oranges and grapes crowdin' a fella outa bed even, I ain't a- goin' to California!  This here's my country. I b'long *here*.  It ain't no good--  --but it's mine.
Now listen, Grampa. Listen to me, just a minute.
All but me! I'm a-stayin'.
But you can't *do* that, Grampa. This here land is goin' under the tractor. We *all* got to git out.
I ain't talkin' about you, I'm talkin' about me. And I'm a-stayin'. I give her a good goin' over all night long-- and I'm a-stayin'.
What you mean you ain't goin'? We *got* to go. We got no place to stay.
'S all right, Grampa. You just kind a tar'd, that's all. Somebody fix a pallet.
*Ain't* a-goin'... ain't a-goin'...
And can't nobody *make* me go, either! Ain't nobody here *man* enough to make me! I'm a-stayin'.
Ma. Pa.  Grampa, his eyes hurt and hunted and frightened and bewildered, scratches in the dirt.
Take her with you!
How 'bout Granma?
Ain't nothin' the matter. I just ain't a-goin', that's all.
What's the matter, Grampa?
I didn't bust out. They lemme out. Howya, Noah. Howya, Uncle John.
You know what I al'ays said: "Tom'll come bustin' outa that jail like a bull through a corral fence." Can't keep no Joad in jail!
I'll walk back.
Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?
You mean I can't even get outa here?
Well, you just turn around and walk the other way.
Thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?
Where you think you're going?
Sure. We aim to.
Okay. Go ahead, but you better keep movin'.
No plants.
Got any plants?
No longer'n we can get acrost her.
How long you plan to be in Arizona?
California.
Where you going?
Okay. I be back a little later.
I got to get a lot curiouser than I am--with all them cops out there.
You git. Go on now, git. You ain't doin' no good. They ain't enough for you.
Wouldn't be no use. I'd still see 'em inside the tent.
You take that plate inside the tent an' you eat it.
I know, but I got a stomickache. I ain't hungry.
Whatta ya mean? You ain't et today.
You take this.  I ain't hungry.
No--an' look what I got for you.
An' you won't let nobody touch me?

You an' me's goin' together--jus' you an' me. We're a-goin' to that dance an' we're a-goin' to jus' set an' watch. If anybody says to come dance--why I'll say you're poorly. But you an' me, we're gonna hear the music an' see the fun.
I can't he'p it, Ma. It don't make *me* giggly an' happy.
Why, honey, it makes folks happy to see a girl that way--makes folks sort of giggly an' happy.
Ma...  Ma, I--I can't go to the dance. I jus' can't Ma. I can't hardly stan' it, with Connie not here--an' me this way.
I know, honey, an' just as soon as we get settled Al's gonna set out an' look for him. How 'bout gas, Tommy?
Ma... you know, if Connie was here I wouldn't min' any a this.
Stand by the door.
No'm.
Anybody ask anything?
This got a floor. Wouldn't leak when it rains.
I like the tent better.
Why, sure. It won't be so bad once we get her washed out.
We gonna live here?
Maybe that's jus' what he done.
Maybe Connie went to get some books to study up with. He's gonna be a radio expert, ya know. Maybe he figgered to suprise us.

No. No, it don't. I can't do that. I can't let m'self. All I can do is see how soon they gonna wanta eat again. They'd all get upset if I done anymore 'n that. They all depen' on me jus' thinkin' about that.  That's my part--that an' keepin' the fambly together.
Don't it ever scare you it won't be nice in California like we think?
Sometimes. A little. Only it ain't scairt so much. It's just waitin' an' wonderin'. But when sump'n happens that I got to do sump'n--  --I'll do it.
You don't ever get scairt, do you, Ma?
They use' to be a sayin': A chile born outa sorrow'll be a happy chile. An' another: Born outa too much joy'll be a doleful boy. That's the way I always heard it.
But will it--hurt the baby?
Well, can't nobody get through nine *months* without sorrow.
Sometimes I'm all jumpy inside.
Now don't you go gettin' nimsy-mimsy.
Ma... all this, will it hurt the baby?

I know. Maybe that makes us tough. Rich fellas come up an' they die, an' their kids ain't no good, an' they die out. But we keep a-comin'. We're the people that live. Can't nobody wipe us out. Can't nobody lick us. We'll go on forever, Pa. We're the people.
Maybe, but we shore takin' a beatin'.
She'll be awright.
Make her easy, John. Watch her.
Don't matter. Just got to go--an' keep a-goin', till we get plenty a distance away from here.
Know where we're a-goin'?
They charge extry at the comp'ny store but they ain't no other place.
That!
It sure is hell jus' tryin' to get enough to eat.
Sump'n got to happen soon. We got one day's more grease, two day's flour, an' ten potatoes. After that...  An' Rosasharn, we got to remember she's gonna be due soon.
How come I got to shh? Run out, didn't he?
Pa! Shh!
Glad to get shet of him. Never was no good an' never will be--
Connie's gone.  Lit out this e'enin'--said he didn't know it was gonna be like this.

Sassy my foot! I'm jus' sick and tar'd a my folks tryin' to bust up. All we got lef' in the *worl'* is the fambly--an' right down at bottom that's all we *got* to have! Ef some of us dies, we can't he'p that--but ain't nobody else runnin' away!
Jus' sassy, that's all.
I never *seen* her so sassy.  An' she ain't so young, neither!
Al ain't a-goin' away, an' you gonna *tell* him he ain't a-goin' away.  An' if you think diff'unt, you gotta whup me first. So some on.
Now don't get sassy, Ma.
You'll *what*?... Come on, Pa. Come on an' whup me. Jus' try it.
Cut it out, Ma, or I'll--
You don't know *no* girls around here. You're lyin', *You're runnin' away*!
Go get Tom an' Al.  I dunno what to do. I got to feed the fambly. What'm I gonna do with these here?
How 'bout it?
Good-by, Tommy.
Sure. Good-by.
Good-by, Tom. Later--when it's blowed over--you'll come back? You'll try to fin' us?
Me neither.  It's jus' stuff I been thinkin' about. Gimme you han', Ma. Good-by.
I don't understan' it, Tom.

Then it don't matter. Then I'll be all aroun' in the dark. I'll be ever'where--wherever you look. Wherever there's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever there's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad--an' I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry an' they know supper's ready. An' when our people eat the stuff they raise, an' live in the houses they build, why, I'll be there too.
Then what, Tom?
Well, maybe it's like Casy says, a fella ain't got a soul of his own, but on'y a piece of a big soul--the one big soul that belongs to ever'body-- an' then...
How'm I gonna know 'bout you? They might kill you an' I wouldn't know. They might hurt you. How'm I gonna know?

No, Ma. Not that. That ain't it. But long as I'm a outlaw, anyways, maybe I can do sump'n. Maybe I can jus' fin' out sump'n. Jus' scrounge aroun' an' try to fin' out what it is that's wrong, an then see if they ain't sump'n could be done about it.  But I ain't thought it out clear, Ma. I can't. I don't know enough.
You don't aim to kill nobody, Tom!
They gonna drive me anyways. Soon or later they'll get me, for one thing if not another. Until then...
Tommy, they'll drive you, an' cut you down like they done to Casy.

I been thinkin' about us, too--about our people livin' like pigs, an' good rich lan' layin' fallow, or maybe one fella with a million acres, while a hundred thousan' farmers is starvin'. An' I been wonderin' if all our folks got together an' yelled--
He was a good man.
You know what I been thinkin' about, Ma? About Casy. About what he said, what he done, an' about how he died. An' I remember all of it.
Awright, Tommy. What you figger you gonna do?
I know you would, Ma. But I ain't gonna let you. You hide somebody that's kilt a man an'... an' you'd be in trouble too.
I could hide you, Tommy.

I'd like to stay. I'd like to be with ya--  --an' see your face when you an' Pa get settled in a nice little place. I sure wish I could see you then. But--  --I guess I won't never be able to do that. Not now.
It had to come, I reckon, soon or later.
They was some cops here, Ma. They was takin' down the license numbers. It looks like somebody knows sump'n.
Girl with a baby *always* gets prettier.
She's gettin' prettier, Ma.
Don't know--but it's better'n this.
What is it?
I'd hate to get *trapped* in here.
It's jus' till we get some distance. Then you can come out.
Comes night we'll get outa here.
That Casy. He might a been a preacher, but--he seen a lot a things clear. He was like a lantern--he helped mw see things too.
Okay, Ma. I shouldn't, though. I know I shouldn't. But okay.

Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us.  They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Ol' folks died off, an' little fellas come, an' we was always one thing-- we was the fambly--kinda whole an' clear. But now we ain't clear no more. They ain't nothin' keeps us clear. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn--  --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.
I'm gonna go away tonight. I can't go puttin' this on you folks.
It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.
I'm sorry, Ma. But--I didn't know what I was doin', no more'n when you take a breath. I didn't even know I was gonna do it.
They know he got hit in the face.
They know what--this fella looks like?
That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.
They killed Casy first.
Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.
I kinda thought so. Felt like it.
Looks like you done it.
Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?
How's it feel, Tommy?
Okay, Ma. Don't you worry.
You be careful, Tommy. Don't you be stickin' your nose in anything.
Well, tomorra you'll get in a full day--full day's pay--an' we'll have plenty.
I ain't full.
No. That's all. You made a dollar, an' that's a dollar's worth.
Got any more, Ma?
You know, I jus' can't remember when I felt so good before!
Get some sugar too, for the coffee.

Fust thing I'll get is coffee, cause ever'body been wantin' that, an' then some flour an' bakin' powder an' meat. Better not get no side- meat right off. Save that for later. Maybe Sat'dy. Got to get some soap too. An' milk. Rosasharn's got to have some milk.
What's that--detour?
You gotta keep clear, Tom. The fambly's breakin' up. You *got* to keep clear.
I'm a-tryin', Ma. Honest I am.
You promised, Tommy.

I know, Ma. I'm a tryin'. If it was the law they was workin' with, we could take it. But it *ain't* the law. They're workin' away at our spirits. They're tryin' to make us cringe an' crawl. They're workin' on our decency.
Tom--you tol' me--you promised you wasn't like that. You promised me.
Ma, they comes a time when a man gets mad.
On a gallon a gas?  Let's set up the tent. Maybe I can fix us up some stew.
She shore don't look prosperous. Want to go somewheres else?

I was afraid they'd stop us an' wouldn't let us cross. But I tol' Granma. I tol' her when she was dyin'. I tol' her the fambly had ta get acrost. I tol' her we couldn't take no chances on bein' stopped.
An' that's why you didn't want 'em to look?
Since before they stopped us las' night.
When?
Granma's dead.
Was Granma bad?
No.
Didn' you get no sleep?
Thank God!  An' we're still together-- most of us.
Look, Ma!
Ya say we're acrost?
Ma, you sick?
Forget it, Ma. Jus' think about the nice things out there. Think about them grapes and oranges--an' ever'body got work--
Maybe they got crimes in California we don't know about. Crimes we don't even know *is* crimes.
Forget it, Ma. I got her figgered out. Long as I keep outa trouble, ain't nobody gonna say a thing. All I gotta do is keep my nose clean.
Your pa tol' me you didn't ought to cross it if you're paroled. Says they'll send you up again.
Yes'm, that was it.
That's right. And douse some in it.
And they's some coffee here. I could fix him a cup...
Don't taste bad.
Wait. There's a half a bottle a soothin' sirup here.  It put the chillun to sleep.
I'm ready.
How about it, Ma?
Thank God. I--I don't want no mean son
No, Ma. You don't have to worry about that.

Sometimes they do somethin' to you, Tommy. They hurt you--and you get mad--and then you get mean--and they hurt you again--and you get meaner, and meaner--till you ain't no boy or no man any more, but just a walkin' chunk a mean-mad. Did they hurt you like that, Tommy?
No, Ma I was at first--but not no more.
Sometimes they do.
Mad, Ma?

We *got* to, Tommy. But that's gonna be awright. I seen the han'bills, about how much work they is, an' high wages, too. But I gotta fin' out somepin' else first, Tommy.  Did they hurt you, son? Did they hurt you an' make you mean-mad?
Muley tol' me what happened, Ma. Are we goin' to California true?
I'd a found you, Ma.
I was so scared we was goin' away without you--and we'd never see each other again.
No, Ma. I'm paroled. I got my papers.
Thank God. Oh thank God.  Tommy, you didn't *bust* out, didya? You ain't got to hide, have you?
Well, give me two then, ma'am.
Oh, them? Well, no--them's *two* for a penny.
There, them stripy ones.
Which ones?
Go ahead--Bert says take it.
I don't wanta rob you, ma'am.
You can have this for ten cents.
Would you--could you see your way to cuttin' off ten cents worth?
This here's a fifteen-cent loaf.
You can't get no loaf a bread for a dime. We only got fifteen-cent loafs.
I shore would like to do that, ma'am, but the fack is, we ain't got but a dime for it. It's all figgered out, I mean--for the trip.
Whyn't you buy a san'wich? We got nice san'widges.
I know, ma'am... on'y it's for a ole lady, no teeth, gotta sof'n it with water so she can chew it, an' she's hongry.
This ain't a groc'ry store. We got bread to make san'widges with.
Could you see your way clear to sell us a loaf of bread, ma'am.
Yeah?
I don't think so. One come out here once an' I clipped him from behin' with a fence stake. They ain't bothered since.
Won't they come out here?
All you got to do is lay down an' watch.
You're *trespassin'*! It ain't you lan' no more! An' that's the supr'tendant--with a gun!
Hide out for what? We ain't doin' nothin'.
Listen!  That's them! Them lights! Come on, we got to hide out!

The rest of my fambly set out for the west--there wasn't nothin' to eat--but I couldn't leave. Somepin' wouldn't let me. So now I just wander around. Sleep wherever I am. I used to tell myself I was lookin' out for things, so when they come back ever'thing would be all right. But I knowed that wan't true. There ain't nothin' to look out for. And ain't nobody comin' back. They're gone-- and me, I'm just an 'ol graveyard ghost--that's all in the world I am.
But it don't seem possible--kicked off like that!
What was the use. He was right. There wasn't a thing in the world I could do about it.
They come. They come and pushed me off.
Well?
That's what I asked you, ain't it?
Some say I am.  You want to hear what happened?
Are you crazy?
Listen!  That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.
But who done it?
Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks.  Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.
But what's happened?  How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.
Gone--  --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got *his* notice to get off.
I know that! But *where* they gone?
They gone.
Muley! Where's my folks, Muley?
Tommy?

Well, I'm right here to tell you, mister, ain't *nobody* going to push me off *my* land! Grampa took up this land seventy years ago. My pa was born here. We was *all* born on it, and some of us got killed on it, and some died on it. And that's what makes it ourn--bein' born on it, and workin' it, and dyin' on it--and not no piece of paper with writin' on it! So just come on and try to push me off!
Brother, I don't know. If I did I'd tell you. But I just don't know *who's* to blame!
Then who *do* we shoot?
It ain't nobody. It's a company.
Who's the Shawnee Land and Cattle Comp'ny?
Now don't go blaming me. It ain't *my* fault.
You mean get off my own land?
I can't help that. All I know is I got my orders. They told me to tell you you got to get off, and that's what I'm telling you.
But we couldn't *do* on any less'n what our share is now.  The chillun ain't gettin' enough to eat as it is, and they're so ragged we'd be shamed if ever'body else's chillun wasn't the same way.

Fact of the matter, Muley, after what them dusters done to the land, the tenant system don't work no more. It don't even break even, much less show a profit. One man on a tractor can handle twelve or fourteen of these places. You just pay him a wage and take *all* the crop.
You're tootin' we're gonna stay.
We gonna stay, ain't we?
Take 'er on down, Al. I'll sign.
No. I'm jus' gonna set awhile an' then go to bed.
Think I'll walk out an' try to fin' out what all that fuss outside the gate was. Anybody wanta come with me?
You wouldn't think jus' reachin' up an' pickin'd get you in the back.
Give 'im a fryin' pan.
I ain't got nothin' in *my* han'.
Just in case. Sit up back an' if anybody tries to climb up--let 'im have it.
Me an' you both.
Ya know, you're the second fella talked like that. I'd like to hear some more about that.
I shore would like to stop here a while an' give her some res' but we on'y got 'bout forty dollars left. I won't feel right till we're there an' all workin' an' a little money comin' in.
She's jus' wore out, that's all.
How's Granma since we got her in the tent?
Got that desert yet. Gotta take her tonight. Take her in the daytime fella says she'll cut your gizzard out.
Casy, won't you say a few words?
Not be so lonesome, either, knowin' his name is there with 'im, not just' a old fella lonesome underground.
I figger best we leave something like this on him, lest somebody dig him up and make out he been kilt.  Lotta times looks like the gov'ment got more interest in a dead man than a live one.
California, here we come!
Here we go!
Ain't no whisky, is they?
Can't tie him. Either we'll hurt him or he'll git so mad he'll hurt his self.  Reckon we could git him *drunk*?
Either we got to tie him up and *throw* him on the truck, or somepin. He can't stay here.
Easy. After all, they ain't but about *twelve* of us, is they?

Sol' things, chopped cotton--even Grampa. Got us about two hunnerd dollars all tol'. Shucked out seventy- five for this truck, but we still got nearly a hunnerd and fifty to set out on. I figger we oughta be able to make it on that.
How you get all this money?
Why, she wasn't no more'n a kid when I went up.
That's Connie Rivers with her. They're married now.  She's due about three-four months.

Look at 'em! Same yella han'bill-- 800 pickers wanted. Awright, this man wants 800 men. So he prints up 5,000 a them han'bills an' maybe 20,000 people sees 'em. An' maybe two-three thousan' starts movin, wes' account a this han'bill. Two- three thousan' folks that's crazy with worry headin' out for 800 jobs! Does that make sense?
But what does *that* prove?
I ain't gonna fret you. Go on!
But what about this?
Awright, go on! Ain't nobody stoppin' ya!
Whatta you think you're talkin' about? I got a han'bill here says good wages, an' I seen it in the papers they need pickers!
We gonna take whatever they got.
Good wages, eh! Pickin' oranges an' peaches?
Maybe he'll be back. We'll leave word for him. Jus' don't cry.
Tom, I jus' don't feel like nothin' a tall. Without him I jus' don't wanta live.
Cut it out, Pa. He'p Al with the truck.  Don't fret, honey. You goin' to be awright.
Aw, sure. This here's jus' a part of it. Ain't no sense a gettin' scairt right off.
Maybe it's nice on the other side. Them pitchers--them little pos'cards-- they was real pretty.
You do not see either!--not yet!
If this don't beat all!  Well, I see you been busy already!
Heh'o Tom.  This is Connie, my husband.
I won't--  --if you won't tell what *I* done!
Please don't.
Lissen. You done busted it. You hear?  But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?
I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!
Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!
Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!
Won't they ketch us?
Come on. Ain't nobody gonna say anything.
It's them white things, made outa dish-stuff, like in the catalogues!
Whatsa matter?
Git up. I got sump'n to show you.
Some, I guess, but mos'ly cow bones.
Man bones?
Tom says if it's day it'll cut you gizzard smack out a you.  I seen a pitcher once. They was bones ever'place.
I wisht it was day.
This here's the desert an' we're right in it!
I never--
Now you done it! You busted it!
Now don't you go monk'ing--
What's this?
I seen 'em b'fore you did.
Jes' like in the catalogues, ain't they!
Well, I reckon you *stan'* in them little rooms--an' water come down outa that there little jigger up there--take a bath!
What's these?
Well, there's plenty of work for you about forty miles north, this road just outside Pixley. Turn east on 32 and look for Hooper's ranch. Tell 'em Spencer sent you.
We can pick anything.
Can you pick peaches?
Mister, we're lookin' even under boards for work.
You people looking for work?
Morning.
Morning.
Ain't gonna get outa han'.
Awright. An' if she gets outa han', I'll be in the right han' corner, this side the dance floor.
Yes, sir.
You ain't to hurt them fellas.
Ain't gonna be no trouble.
You sure you got ever'thing ready?
Shore looks like my lucky day, anyway. Gettin' some work at las'.
Lotta these little farmers mighty nice fellas. Trouble is they're little, they ain't got much say-so.
Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's and just change them to special barbecue sauce.
--No.
You know those horsey biscuit gravy packets? I move all of those--
--Stop it--
I sell biscuits and gravy all over the Southland--
You're so funny...
It's what I do.
You do not.
I sell biscuits to the Southland.
What do you do?
Yeah...
Oh... really?
In the corporate offices.
You don't...
Yes I do.
You do not.
I work at Kentucky Fried Chicken.
But wait. I still don't understand what you do.
Whatever I can get away with.
So, what are you doing now?
Wonderful.
We had pictures put on, that way everybody knows who everybody was!
Don't say that.
Marty, you haven't changed a bit!
I'm Martin Blank.
Welcome back! I'm Arlene Oslott- Joseph.
Sure. Listen. Why don't you join us up in the grandstands?
Remember high school?
Not much, actually. My software company just went public so I'm just... hanging out, really.
I sell BMW's. What do you do?
Yeah... Hey, I saw you at your dad's dealership the other day.
Computer guy.
I'm Dan. Dan Koretzky.
What?
Bob. Bob Destephano.
Then express yourself, Bob.
I want to be an actor.
What do you want to do?
What am I gonna do?
You could've been a contender, huh?
Ahhh... it's all fucked up. Nothing adds up to nothing... you work your whole life, day in and day out-- try to make sense of it all. One day you're twenty-seven and what do you get to show for it...
Really?
Never better.
Fine, Bob. How are you?
So. You and Debi. Gonna hit that shit again?
Okay. See you later.
Really...? So what?
It's me. Martin Blank.
What?
Bob...
Overflowing with love.
Jesus...
To make a long story short...
Insane.
Basically the same thing. In a very evolved, esoteric way.
A Jew, a shaman, and a herbalist are telling you the same thing? You're insane.

That's a tragedy. Can I finish my story please? I began my search for meaning. I was a Catholic, Jew, Scientologist, Sufi, Buddhist. I went to a Psychologist, psychiatrist, herbalist, nutritionist, a shaman, and a psychic. And they all pretty much say the same stuff.
It seemed like my life was slipping away, somehow. I was a knot in the middle of a wet rope. Everything was futile and nothing had value.
He gets this way when he hits over eighty-five.
I'd come to the realization that everything I'd based my life on was false. And that my life had no meaning.
Correct.  That's for you. Keep it.
And these pan pizzas have opened up the doors to heaven?
Yes.
So you eat-- read it everyday?
You open 'em up and there's the sayings, stories, little bites of insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day Week.
Oh I see. You got your individual slices of hope, dignity, confidence, self-love, justice, and harmony.
Other people can't.
I have no illusions about the future. What is, is. We make choices. And we become the sum total of our choices. I can live with that.
You kill people.
That's because I speak human, and you speak monster.
You don't understand...
You don't get to have me. You are a monster, I'm a human being. We're not going to mate.
I'll hide.
What if I come back?
I'm staying here.
Will you come with me?
That's probably a good idea.
I was leaving.
You never could have kept this from me.
A sociopath kills for no reason. I kill for money.
Let me help you along, Martin. You're a sociopath!
Like, that there's a point? An organic connection between all living things.
Okay. Great, Martin, that's just great. Meaning to life... Mmm....

Then I started losing my taste for it. Which usually means your time is up. But then I realized it was something entirely different... I started getting the sneaking, dark suspicion that maybe there was... meaning to life.
Jesus Christ!

I was, but no... yes... I was before, but now I'm not. It's irrelevant, really. The idea of governments, nations, it's mostly a public relations theory at this point, anyway. But I'll tell you something, until about five months ago, I really enjoyed my work.
You're a government spook?

Seriously, when I left, I joined the Army and took the service exam. They found my psych results fit a certain profile. A certain "Moral flexibility" would be the best way to describe it... I was loaned out to a CIA- sponsored program. It's called "mechanical operations." We sort of found each other...
Get the fuck outta here.
...About five years now.
It's something I do...
Is it something you've done?
No.
Not the other way around...?
Yes.
He was trying to kill you, right!
Could be. The physical substance of love.
Like love?
Too junky-kitschy. Deeper, deeper.
Like heroin?
Even though I left, you never left me. Not just memory but a substance in my blood.
Okay, then. Clearly candied Diller.
No time.
Wow. I have to give this some thought.
It's just a game...! Alright. Candied Diller, or... wear a hot pork vest across the desert with a fully digested crab apple in your mouth?
--She's not dead---
Soft. I'll take the junkie otter, clearly! I'd let the little beast scratch and claw all he wants... Okay. Would you rather make love to the candied corpse of Phyllis Diller--

Okay... Would you rather... commit yourself sexually to a four-by-nine cell with former President George Herbert Walker Bush dressed as a super-model for a month, or make love to a otter on crank for a week?
Which would you rather...?
We haven't seen each other since high school.
--Yes. Actually we just bought that little Frank Lloyd Wright on Pine Avenue... Debi's a social worker and I mow down insurance claims at Aetna--
What?
Shoulda brought my gun.
Right.
I think they'll probably have booze there.
Do you want to get a drink first?
I'll just help myself to a cocktail.
...Let me get my coat.
Okay... Hold on...
You look beautiful.
Here. Let me put these in some rubbing alcohol.
As long as I get the laugh.
Flowers. That's funny.
Don't rush to judgement until all the facts are in.
You're fucking psycho.
This night, this reunion will be an important step in our relationship.
Hello...?
Pick me up at my father's house at around seven. And don't be late this time.
Yes.
Are you there?
I'll think about it.
Seven it is.
Unbelievable.
Yes.
Let me get this straight, are you asking me out?

That's not true.
Who's ever going to want me? Nobody will.
What?... Oh baby...
Who's going to want me now?
I felt it happen downstairs and when I went into the bathroom.
When? Tonight?
My period.
Started what?
I said... I started.
What did you say?
LEAVE ME ALONE!!

Well, then I do apologize... But what I'm most sorry for is turning you into a spoiled brat who can only think about what she's feeling... who can't admit when she's wrong and who can't forgive when she's not.
Yeah, well, you've done a great job.

Listen, if... if there's a part of you as parent that... that takes pride in your child -- that, you can look at them and see something you've accomplished as well... if that's wrong, then I'm sorry.  But it wasn't my intention. I don't push for me. I do it for you... So you don't waste half your life feeling like you don't know where you belong.

FOR YOU! Because I'm your daughter which means you're the best mother! Isn't that what you're always talking about in interviews -- having it all, the great career, the great family... Proving everybody wrong. Wanting everybody to think you're this perfect woman!
I don't deserve that. I have never looked at you as a disappointment. If I'm on your back to do better, if I push you to try harder it's because I want you to be the best you can be.
Well, now you know what it feels like.

WHAT?! How can you --  I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom bothers you so much, but I happen to value having someone to talk to, especially when my own daughter ignores me night and day because no matter what I say, it's wrong and no matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm sorry I'm such a disappointment to you.
NO, YOU STOP IT! Stop pretending like you care! Like this really isn't about you and Tom.
STOP IT! Why can't I talk to you!!
Yeah, you know everything!!
Look, I just wanted to say, I think it's great you're riding again. And... and I think I know why you, you needed to do it alone... without anyone knowing...
Tom?
I was just trying to say thank you to Diane and Frank and --
I can't remember the last time you made him dinner.
Grace, I don't hate your father.
You... not wanting to go home because you hate daddy so much.
What are you talking about?
... You worried everything all right now and we'll have to go home?
Honey, nobody's trying to cure you --
Yeah. Does that mean I'm cured?!
Well...  So you tried riding again?
About what?
Grace? Is everything all right?  Can we talk?
Did you go riding?
Nothing.
Thanks, honey.
I'll take care of it.
Does anybody out there want something to drink?
You're right. Good.
Mom, they don't mind eating with one fork.
Well, one was for salad...
I thought there were too many forks on the table.
Uh, I don't, honey. Branding? Oooh... I think we'd just be in Mr. Booker's way.
I'll come.
No. I just thought... forget it.
Why? There's no food in the house?
Honey, come on. Would you like to stay in town for dinner? Maybe see what movie's playing tonight?
If I had everything I need, I wouldn't be going to physical therapy.
You got everything you need?
Yeah, he's going to think about it. You want me to pack for you?
Did he mention it?
You already did.
Did you ask him to come visit?
Hi.
We'll have more room because we're moving onto the ranch. They have this empty house near this creek. It's actually pretty... OK... I love you.  Dad wants to talk to you.
I think they call it a pasture.
He's still sitting in that damn field.
I didn't see it.
There was supposed to be a turn off. Did I miss it?
What would they say? "Ten miles to big rock." "Twenty miles to bigger rock."
Don't they believe in signs here?
Gee, this looks like a fun place.
Little.
You buckled up?  You cold?
No, you just act like you do.
It's... it's not that simple to explain. I know you think it is, but it's not. The truth is, I don't really know what I want to do. I don't have all the answers.
Then why do you want to leave?
That's not true!
He doesn't have to! It's, like, so obvious you can't stand him.
Did he tell you that?

You're amazing! You act like I don't live in that house! Don't you think I hear the two of you!? Don't you think I can tell what's going on? I'm not five years old, Mom!  You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy doesn't want to.
That's not true! Whatever problems your father and I are having, have nothing to do with this.
You just want to get away from Daddy and you're using me to do it!
I don't believe this!
Bullshit! It's about you! About you deciding! About you always being right! You always getting everything your way, controlling everybody -- like we work for you or something!
Who do you think I'm doing this for? I'm doing this for you!
What are you asking me for? You didn't ask me if I wanted to come in the first place -- now I get to decide? Forget it!
Do you want us to turn around and go back home? Do you?
You know what I mean?  Is this it now? Is this the way we're going to be from now on?
What?
How long is this going to go on?
You were never thirteen, Mom.
This'll be nice. We haven't seen any of the sights yet. It's history. When I was thirteen I used to love seeing things like this.
I don't care.
I don't care.
Would you like to see that?
You don't.
I didn't know I had to.
Oh. You didn't tell me.
I already did.  This morning. When you went running.
You should call your dad before it gets too late.
Fine.
Fine!
Whatever you want.
IT'S ALMOST LUNCHTIME. ARE YOU HUNGRY!?
I don't care.
Look, if you want to take it in the morning, that's fine.
-- enough time tomorrow. I know.
No, I don't mean you have to. It's just that we may not have enough --
Fine -- I'll take my bath.
You want to take your bath?  We have to get up early tomorrow. You may not have enough time to --
I mean, I'm not much use anymore. Why can't they be compassionate to me?
What?
Maybe they should put me down too.
Yeah?
Mom?
I think that's... very compassionate and... mature way of looking at it.
I think we should. It's not fair to let him suffer. He's not much use anymore. He'd hate living like that.
Well... how you feel all right about telling Liz to put him down...
What about him?
Have you decided about Pilgrim?
Doesn't matter.
Grace, I put it on the table near your --
No, you didn't.
I brought it to you in the hospital.
I can't find that charm Daddy gave me from India.
It's still early. What's your next class?
Fine!
You are not staying home all day feeling sorry for yourself. You're going to get up and you're going to figure this out.
Is that your version of a pep talk?
Grace, listen to me. Your body is just healing. You have to give the rest of you time as well...
I'm not coming back! That's it! I want to go home!
Oh. Well, what are you going to do? You have to go to school, honey. I mean, what --
Doesn't matter. I... I don't want to come back, that's all.
Oh, honey... What happened?
Okay.
Dad'll pick you up today, all right?
I don't want to lie down. I've been lying down enough.
Why don't you go lie down?
I can't even get out of bed yet! You're already putting me in therapy!!
Liz is taking care of him.  The doctor said the sooner you start therapy the better the chances are you can --
All right. Speak to you then.
Uh, yes... Sure, David.
If this magazine is so important to you Annie, why are you in Montana?
What the hell does that mean? How much more do I have to do to prove how important this magazine is to me?
Lucy isn't you. We're losing something without you being here. Now, I know this is a rough time for you, but I think we should make another arrangement.
Oh, come on! This is such bullshit! The work is getting done, David. Lucky keeps me on top of everything.
Exactly...
Well, I suppose we could use another good public feud...
David, he signed an agreement that he wouldn't talk to the press and he's libeled me by saying I faked the figures. You're not going soft on me, are you?
Is that absolutely necessary? It'll just make it a bigger story.
Yes. We're suing.
Did you speak to Farlow?
Everyone. Working overtime. Just for you.
Who's there?
David?
I don't know. Let's just go and... we'll see...
Where to?
You want to take a walk with me?
I have so much to tell you.
Mmm. I made good time.  Pilgrim's in the back. I found a new stable, but they can't take him until tomorrow.
Was the trip okay?
Tubab means white man.
What do you mean?
No. I am a "tubab."
Hi. Um, there doesn't seem to be any hotel room available and someone told me to come here and ask for "Tubab" who might to have a place for me to stay. Are you "Tubab"?
Yes?

And I have two choices. I can either fight the way things are, or accept them.  See, I always knew I loved you more. Didn't bother me. I always felt lucky... a little amazed... that such a vibrant, beautiful woman would want to be with a man like me... And I guess I thought as long as I did everything right -- if I was the best husband I could be, the best father... even being a good lawyer only mattered to me because of what it meant for us... if I could do all that, it wouldn't make any difference if we loved each other the same or not... I wasn't asking for more. I told myself I didn't need more.  But you don't know how you feel about me. You don't know... if you want a life with me anymore...  And I don't want you to come home until you do know...  ... one way or the other.
I don't understa-
I'll tell you something, Annie -- I stood there looking at what was happening to that horse... And, I swear, it felt like the same thing was happening to me.
What do you mean?
Take your time.
Yeah, what?
May I have a suggestion?
Probably first thing in the morning. It's too late to start now. I'm going to try not to do too much driving in the dark.
Connecticut. I told the office I'd work out of there next week. When are you planning to start back?
Are you going to stay in the city or go up to Connecticut?
Let's not talk about that now.
How are you feeling about work?
No, it's okay. Believe me, there were plenty of times I didn't know what the hell was right.
You were right about coming here. I'm sorry for not thinking...
I can see why you put your faith in him. He's a genuine... good guy... Good at what he does. That's rare.
You don't have to explain. You have every right to come.
I apologize for the surprise, but the days only opened yesterday and I figured...
You're allergic to hay.
Small bed. Maybe I should sleep in the barn.

Honey, I hope you're not endangering your position. Listen, if you need to come back and you want me to come take over, for a while, I'll work it out. I mean, the firm's got other lawyers, but the magazine's got only one of you.
Oh. I didn't look at my faxes today. We left before sunrise.

Apparently, Gottschalk's been seen around town lunching with some very prominent magazine editors. Lucy said she tried to call you, but no one answered so she faxed you the list of names. She said one of them have contracts up fairly soon.
About what?
Well, uh the real reason I called, actually, was to tell you I saw Lucy at Jo-Jo's tonight and she seems very worried.
I wish I did.
Fine. Actually, today was a good day. You should have seen her.
Huh-huh. You?
Everything all right.
Oh well... branding will do that to you.
Oh, Robert, I'm sorry. We were so tired from the branding. Grace barely made it to her bed and I didn't have the energy to take my clothes off.
I thought you guys were going to call me.
Night.
Good night.
I know. We miss you too.
I miss you, Annie.
Okay.
Well then... maybe I will take some time... come visit.
You know, I just asked that myself tonight. He doesn't know.
When are you coming home?
Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy tells me she thinks Gottchalks's plotting, but what else is new.
So, how are you doing in Marlboro country? Is the magazine complaining at all?
Well, it's good that you're there.
Taking forever. I just got an additional list of sixty-two employees to interview before Monday. I don't know how I'm going to do it.

Yeah. She seems to be getting more comfortable on the ranch, which is why I said yes to this move. But, whenever it's just the two of us, I don't know... Anyway... what's happening with the Delco lawsuit?
No, that's not what I said. I'm not a dictator. If you feel you should come, then come. Just do whatever you think is right.
And you think it's best if I don't come.
She will if you think she should.
What if she doesn't want to go?

Robert, we're losing her. We're losing her.  I don't care what the doctors say. The truth is, they don't know anymore than we do -- less, when it comes to Grace... This may not sound sensible or... logical, but nobody's suggesting anything better. I can't explain it, Robert. I just have this feeling... this annoying... bloody feeling that if... if, somehow, Pilgrim can be made all right... then so can Grace. I just know it!
I really wish I could understand why you think this is so necessary.
I'm not pretending anything!
I don't care what he says! We have to do something, Robert! I can't sit here and trust everything's going to work out just by pretending it will.
Are you a psychiatrist? He said it takes time.
I can't say he's been all that effective with her.
Her psychiatrist... said... she needs security now... stability...
Why?!
No. It's, uh... No, I really don't think it's a good idea

I'm in charge. I went back very soon after the accident. They didn't expect me for a couple of months. I'll just take that time now... I can still oversee things from Montana... Take my fax... My computer...
What... Bo-... What about the magazine?
He'll be sedated. I know horses, Robert. I'm the one who taught Grace how to ride.
You want to do this by yourself? How? You can't take care of Pilgrim all the --
I'm not asking you to. I'll do it.
I come home and you tell me we're going to drive a psychotic horse to Montana! I can't just pick up and leave...
No. I was just researching. Calm down.
You've already made arrangements!?
I've called Liz. They can set me up with a trailer for Pilgrim. I thought we'd stay at motels along the way...
NO! What are you -- you're serious about this?
Robert, Grace isn't adjusting to school. And she can't sit in this apartment all day... I think it would be good for her.
That's the craziest thing I ever heard. Absolutely not.
He did, but... I think I can change his mind.
I don't understand. You just said he said no.
About us going someplace warm... Someplace Grace'll have to wear shorts or bathing suits or summer dresses...
What was I saying?
No.
What did he say?
Yeah.
Did you get a hold of that horse guy?
They're still our friends, Annie. It's nothing serious. You kid about them all the time... And I could tell Paul really appreciated me being there.
Why did you go?

All our "favorite" people were there saying all their "favorite" things about their "favorite" subjects. I thought to myself, we've been friends with these people almost twenty years and nobody knows anybody. We're so afraid we won't like each other and have nobody go to dinners with.
How was the dinner?
Helping all the time! Running to her every time she trips or falls... Anticipating her all the time.
Doing what?
You've got to stop doing that?
Do you? Do you really?
I love you.
Aw... that's so sweet.
I had to excuse myself from a meeting. It's ridiculous. I kept thinking about the baby... you... and, I swear, I was going to start bawling right into my briefs.
You can hardly get your arms around me. How depressing. You're so early.
How's my pregnant chick!
Sing it to me, Frankie!
"... FRESH, WIND IN HER HAIR... LIFE WITHOUT CARE... SHE'S BROKE... BUT IT'S 'OK'...
Oh. Right. I'll call him.
... And uh... Mario called about moving the wisteria?
It's on the table by the phone. I didn't know what to tell him...  ... Whether or not we were...  ... if we still we're thinking of redoing the couch.
Okay.
Oh, uh, I meant to tell you... Alex brought that fabric over...
The funeral's on Friday.
We're very lucky.
I saw Judith's parents while you were at the apartment...  I wanted to say something...  But I... I was so relieved that Grace was still... that it wasn't our daughter.
No, I'll go. You stay... In case she wakes up.
No, let me go.
I should go get some of her things.
Nothing new. He's just going off duty.
What did he say?
Tch. What are you --
I'm sorry.
Robert, you leave it up these people...!
No, it's got a little left. They'll be in to change it.
That bag's almost empty.
She was in pretty bad shape. They've done a C.A.T. Scan -- she has some hemorrhaging...
What about Grace?
Yeah. Bye.
Okay. We'll see you later then.
I don't know. We'll figure it out.
That's okay. We have to talk about it and we're not always in the same place ... so... I just have to get used to it.  What do you want to do about dinner?
I'm sorry about last night. I shouldn't have brought it up over the phone.
Riding with Judith.
Sure... What's Grace up to?
Okay. You want me to pick you up?
I should be in by two.
So, what, uh, what train are you taking?
Hi.
Hi.
It's me.
Either fight the way things are or accept it.
What choice!!?
No. He had the choice.
It's so cruel.
Absolutely. I made enough for an army.
I'll have another round of that spaghetti if may?
We have a business manager. The best around.
Well, did you ever think about hiring a business manager?
Well, I know Peterson's. Old place is as good as falling down around your ears.
Oh, I don't know...
Nobody's using it. Silly for her to be driving back and forth when she don't know her way around that well...
Well, get born a bull, got a ninety percent chance of getting castrated and served up as hamburger. On a balance I reckon I'd choose being a cow.  Would you mind passing that salad young lady?

You know, that's interesting. I always wondered when I went into a restaurant what was the difference between a regular steak or a Black Angus steak. I couldn't taste any difference although I could swear one was more tender. I didn't know there was that big a difference between cows...  I've never been on a cow farm before. I must say, the bulls seem to have the best time of it. Just laying around the fields all day until they're asked to...  do their... work.
You too, Diane.
Good luck to you, Annie.
Promise.
Promise?
It's just one night. If I get uncomfortable, I'll go over to Hanks.
I already know the way... and it's not like I have a job I have to rush home for.  Between you and me, I could use the time alone.
Now, are you sure you want to drive that horse back yourself? There are plenty of people 'round here who do that sort of thing.
Oh, how sweet.
I think I'm going to have my hands full with the son of mine when you leave. Just might be his first broken heart.
No, no, I'll go -- just give me a list.
Well, I am going to go after lunch.
Is there anything you need? I'm going food-shopping.

He's a good man, Tom is. He's got a gift, come from heaven above, I swear. But he's still a man. And a woman can lead a man into the middle of a mountain lake -- and still make him think he's on dry land.
I don't think anybody can make Tom do anything he didn't want.

Annie, I'm not good at this kind of talk -- goes round and round a thing but never comes to it -- so let's just say what it is. When you first came here, I didn't like you and I was worried. Tom means a lot to me and this family. Don't go looking here for whatever you looking for. Don't make that man go through something it took him a long time to see his way clear out of the first time.
What?
Yes, it does.
Sounds like something Tom would say.

They don't come better. But I don't deny there are times I wonder about things I won't have. Maybe one day I'll get to see Egypt. Maybe not. But I know if you try too many different lives, you can wind up with no life at all...
Frank's a good man.

I fell in love. After that, I never thought about being anything but a rancher's wife. I never saw it like I was losing some other life, just felt like I was gaining one. I know that's not a popular opinion nowadays and I ain't saying it's the right one. We all have to find the life meant for us.
Did you always know this was the life you wanted?
Guess you don't have to figure it out until you go home.
Delayed shock. Or maybe not. I know I could talk my way back if I wanted or... go to another magazine, someplace... Just not sure if I want to.
You don't seem to upset?
No, it's more like a leave of-  Ha, ha, ha. Yeah, they fired me.
They fired you?
Well, I have more than a few days, ha, ha... I uh... I'm sort of... not an editor anymore... right now... First time I've said it out loud.
Must be nice for you to take a few days off from your work, huh?
Soon. We're going to Branson, Missouri to see my cousin Emma married. Frank loves in there.
You and Frank ever take a vacation?
I'd love to go there one time...

But, uh, Egypt is, well, it's like nothing else. It's like going back in time.  I remember as a kid trying to imagine what a kid my age, centuries ago, walking over that same ground, was wondering about or, if they had the same problems as me... and I felt, connected to... to time itself, almost. Ha, I never realized how hard it was to describe.
Oh, God -- I think it was the fourth or fifth time I'd been there, so all I remember was the heat and how incompetent the photographer was...
What was it like?
I was there for that shot, actually.
I was looking in one of your magazines and saw that picture of the couple getting married at the Pyramids. Were you ever in Egypt?
No reason you should, no reason you should.
Well... I know I should reject that offer, but I'm not going to.
I'll help you with the coffee.
Oh, it's... I wanted to tell you that, if you'd like, you being so busy, I could take Grace to her therapy exercises for you. I have to go in once a week for shopping anyway.
Thank you. You're all doing too much.
I got a little confused though. The ranch Ellen was talking about -- that's not this one?

Ha, she loves telling this story about how when he was two years old, he ran off. They found him in the barn, sleeping between two giant hooves of a Percheron stallion. She said that horse was protecting him and nobody could convince her otherwise.
Always did. I think she favored him a little. You tend to when you have more than one, even though you love 'em all the same.
She calls him Tommy...
Mm-mm. I never knew him. He died before Frank and I met. This here's...  Frank and Tom's mother and father... there's little Frank and Tom...
Oh, you can just set up on the dining table. I have to rearrange my shelves tomorrow.
Where does this go, Diane?
It's fine. Comfortable. I still can't get used to how dark it gets around here, though. When we leave the ranch, I always hold my breath until I can see the motel.
How's Peterson's holding up for you?
No imposition. Plenty of food. Gonna get pretty dark soon. Hard to find a place.
Oh uh, thank you. No, we don't want to impose.
Mrs. MacLean -- why don't you and daughter stay for dinner?
Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near the hill? Yeah.
Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is this the way to the pasture?
Sure.  Does your daughter want to come inside?
Would you mind if I did? I'd like to talk to him.
There's coffee inside... I was just bringing this to Tom.
Probably best. You may want to shoot yourself half way to Ohio.
Of course not.
Problem is, there aren't many volunteers. He's already had enough to sink a battleship. You have a pin, just in case?
Maybe we should give him another sedative.

And I can say the same thing about my daughter! But she is suffering! Can you solve that problem!  I can't deal with this now, Liz! If you need a yes or no right now, then no -- don't do it! Not until I know Grace is all right. Now, please! Just do what you can. Okay?  Please.
It isn't right to make him suffer...
... I just don't know right now! Do whatever you can and when Grace is --
Annie, no matter what I do, this horse will never be the same.
- See, what you can do for him --...
I understand, but Annie, please...
Liz, listen, the Doctor's here and I just can't, uh... talk now... so --
Well, of course, right...
Yes, but he's in a tremendous pain...
Wait, uh, I, I don't understand. Start again -- He's alive...
Oh God, Annie, I'm so sorry. I... I know you're being hit with a low now, I don't want to take too much of your time but I have to talk to you about Pilgrim.
Her leg was shattered so they had to, uh... remove it. She had some bleeding but it's under control.
Annie, it's Liz. How's Grace?
Frank's touchy about his cousins.  Well, it was nice to meet you, Mr. MacLean.
Diane!

Oh Frank, don't forget the wedding present -- it's behind the door in the laundry room.  I got her a pasta maker from the catalogue... Not that they'll know what to do with it in Branton, Missouri... Probably use it as a planter.
You!
Play that sweet one you know. The one makes my wife here so friendly.
It's got doors, Diane. Private as can be. Tom?
They're already all settled in, Frank. Anyway, I'm sure Annie wants her privacy.
I believe women from New York eat mixed salads. Ain't that right, Tom?
What?
Mixed salad.
I guess they'll want feeding and all, out here all day long.
Oh hell, I don't know... According to Tom, she's a pretty determined woman. Must've thought it was worth it.

... well, I just think she's got a lot of nerve showing up here. Draggin' that child and that poor animal all the way...  You eat with those fingers again and you know what'll happen!  Frank, don't you think she's got a nerve?
No thanks.
I have some brownies left over. Want one?
Ain't brain surgery.
Diane takes care of the books. I don't know how, but at the end of every month, everything adds up to the penny.
Ha...
Well, that's just what we need on a cattle ranch -- a vegetarian from New York.
I believe so. Saw it on a television show, once.
What, they ain't going forty miles into Choteau everytime they want a hamburger.
I don't believe they'll expect that.
Be honest, I can't say I did it all myself. My grandma helped me get the words right.
Now son, you tell 'em when it came from.
Tell her they suit the weather better. Their udders are black, 'stead of pink.
Teacher asked me why we raise Black Angus-Herefords 'stead of Pure Herefords.
Weekend after next...
When you figure on branding?

There was this thing on the TV about a guy who does it with geese. He has this airplane and these baby geese all grow up thinking it's their mom, and he flies it and they just follow.  You hear 'bout that, Uncle T?
That's what some folks say.
He says if you do it soon as they're born, it makes them real easy to handle later on.
There's a kid at school says we should've imprint-trained him.
Sure. As long as she don't mind.
Can we take a look at Bronty's foal when we're done here, Dad?
He thought it was a ghost.

We thought we lost him in the snow storm... Told the kids. Had a funeral for the damn thing. Finally, snow stops. Staring to warm up. I go out and start cleaning the truck... Goddamn if that dog doesn't jump out from the back seat covered in snow... I nearly stained myself.
I don't think Warren would go for that.
It'd be a whole lot easier to pay the feed end of the month...
And next time, Miss Annie, you can run down the calves...
Well, I'd like to welcome Annie and Grace to their first branding...
Our daddy raised Pure Herefords.
They don't get burned by the sun bouncing off the snow. And they're good mother.
We should be fine, then.
Bank out us a couple more men to run the cattle.
Yeah.
Tom?
You know her?
I don't believe it.
You know, you're a good kid.
I wouldn't let happen.
I don't thinks you'd want me tripping all over you in front of everybody.
You wouldn't want to dance with me, would you?
I don't know... You sure Tom said it's all right?
Of course I have.
Have you talked to Tom about it?
Would you let me ride your horse?
Because it fits my head. You want to try it on?
Why do you always wear that hat?
Twice a month they give you a day off to work on the ranch.
Don't you go to school?
Grace, Listen... you've got to do this. Just trust me one more time.
No!
He's not hurt. He's okay. Look at him.
No, you're only going to hurt him some more.
Grace, I need you to come with me.
I want to watch.

It's more or less how it sounds. Sometimes it's not pretty to watch. Some horses fight it real hard. Your fella's already shown us he likes a good fight. So if you don't want to watch, I'll call you when it's done.
What does that mean?
There's still something going on inside of him I can't reach. So me and Smokey here, we're going to try laying him down. Okay?
Sure.
Sure?
There's no hurry. Take you time.
